p: Several popular mechanisms, as shown in Figure 5, have been reported and concluded by researchers. Firstly, the electrostatic interaction between the positively charged cationic polymer or free metal ions, and the negatively charged bacterial membrane could destroy the cell integrity. This effect might induce the increase of both hole formation and permeability of the membrane [ 17, 31, 78, 88, 113, 114, 115, 116]. Secondly, photocatalytic reaction of NPs under UV and visible lights could induce the generation of reactive oxygen species (ROS) and hydrogen peroxide on the surfaces of particles [ 13, 15, 100]. This oxidative damages to proteins and DNA in the cell could provide the mainly contribution to the antimicrobial activity of NPs [ 15, 31, 76, 100, 117]. Finally, the detachment of free metal ions could disturb the DNA replication [ 13, 18, 97, 117]. However, continuous investigations are carried out to obtain more information on and better understand the antimicrobial mechanisms of NPs.
